<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN PAGE WIDTH -->
<A name='145'>
<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Compensation
    Process</FONT></B>
</DIV>
</A>
<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Compensation reflects an employee&#146;s value to Agrium&#146;s
    business, including the market value of the skills the employee
    brings to the business, the value of the employee&#146;s
    individual contribution and the business results that are
    generated as a result of employee efforts. In order to ensure
    that Agrium appropriately assesses and compensates senior
    executives, Agrium uses the following compensation process:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <IMG src="o53616o5361614.gif" alt="(FLOW CHART)">
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Persons
    Involved in Compensation Process</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Board has responsibility for overseeing Agrium&#146;s
    compensation program. As is set out under
    &#147;Section&#160;Three: Corporate Governance&#160;&#151; Human
    Resources&#160;&#038; Compensation Committee&#148; (above), the
    Board has delegated certain oversight responsibilities to the
    HR&#038;C Committee, but retains final authority over some
    aspects of the compensation program and process including
    approval of material amendments to or adoption of new
    equity-based compensation plans and review and approval of
    HR&#038;C Committee recommendations regarding executive
    compensation.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In designing the various elements and determining amounts of
    compensation, the HR&#038;C Committee draws upon the expertise
    of the Chair of the HR&#038;C Committee, the CEO and the Senior
    Human Resources Officer and confers with Agrium&#146;s General
    Counsel and CFO on matters that fall within their respective
    realms of responsibility.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Agrium&#146;s Senior Human Resources Officer provides the
    HR&#038;C Committee with internal and external analyses
    regarding the basic structure and competitiveness of
    Agrium&#146;s compensation program and the details of
    Agrium&#146;s various compensation and incentive plans. Each
    year, the Senior Human Resources Officer also provides the
    committee with a detailed review of the estimated and actual
    results for each performance measure compared to threshold,
    target and maximum goals and the resulting estimated and actual
    payments to the executive officers. The HR&#038;C
    Committee&#146;s interactions with the Senior Human Resources
    Officer include at least one meeting in which no other members
    of management are present.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Agrium relies on its compensation consultant, Towers Perrin, to
    assist it in various aspects of the compensation process. The
    assistance provided by the consultant in 2008 includes:
    (i)&#160;assisting the HR&#038;C Committee in updating and
    evaluating the appropriateness of the peer companies that it
    uses to evaluate the competitiveness of Agrium&#146;s executive
    compensation program; (ii)&#160;undertaking competitive reviews
    of senior executive and board of director
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    39
</DIV><!-- END PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN PAGE WIDTH -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    compensation levels; (iii)&#160;providing peer company
    information to the Board; (iv)&#160;supporting the HR&#038;C
    Committee in the review of material and recommendations that are
    originated by management, (v)&#160;providing information on
    trends in compensation design to the HR&#038;C Committee and the
    Human Resources Department; and (vi)&#160;assisting the Human
    Resources Department with changes to the design of the
    compensation program. In addition, Towers Perrin undertakes
    forward and back testing of compensation paid to select NEOs on
    request of the HR&#038;C Committee.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    A senior representative of Towers Perrin met with the full Board
    and participated in portions of three (out of four) HR&#038;C
    Committee meetings in 2008. During those meetings, the HR&#038;C
    Committee met with the Towers Perrin representative without the
    CEO or members of management present. In the course of preparing
    for those meetings, the Towers Perrin representative conferred
    with the HR&#038;C Committee Chair and the Senior Human
    Resources Officer.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Determining
    Compensation Mix</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    On an annual basis, the HR&#038;C Committee reviews
    Agrium&#146;s executive compensation program, including the mix
    of compensation offered and the appropriateness of short, medium
    and long-term performance-based opportunities. The CEO and the
    Senior Human Resources Officer advise the HR&#038;C Committee
    regarding the competitiveness of the compensation program and
    their impact on Agrium&#146;s ability to attract, motivate and
    retain talented employees and executives. In addition, the
    HR&#038;C Committee reviews information about the compensation
    programs of peer group companies, with whom Agrium competes for
    human resources. Peer group information is used to set target
    level compensation for Agrium executives and to ensure
    appropriate performance objectives are set to attain target
    levels of compensation. See &#147;Basis for Compensation
    Decisions&#160;&#151; Peer Groups&#148; (below) for more
    information regarding the selection of Agrium&#146;s peer groups.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The design and administration of specific elements of
    compensation is the responsibility of Agrium&#146;s Human
    Resources Department, with input and approval, where necessary,
    from the HR&#038;C Committee and with the assistance of the
    compensation consultant. Typically, strategic decisions on the
    compensation program are considered by the HR&#038;C Committee
    over the course of more than one meeting before final approval
    is given.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Setting
    Performance Objectives and Goals</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The CEO, in consultation with the Board and senior management,
    is responsible for developing the Corporation&#146;s overall
    strategic plan. On the basis of the strategic plan, the CEO
    develops an annual business plan and sets out proposed corporate
    goals, strategies and objectives, which are reviewed and
    approved by the Board. In February of each year, the CEO, the
    Chair of the Board and the Chair of the HR&#038;C Committee meet
    and establish compensation objectives, which are linked to the
    Corporation&#146;s strategic and annual business plans. These
    objectives include both general corporate and financial
    objectives used to assess performance for the purpose of annual
    incentive compensation of senior management and individual
    performance criteria that will be used to assess the performance
    of the CEO. In some circumstances, the compensation objectives
    may diverge from the Corporation&#146;s strategic and annual
    business plans, and the HR&#038;C Committee specifically
    discusses and considers the merits of and the reasons for any
    such divergence. The final corporate and CEO performance
    objectives are approved by the HR&#038;C Committee.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The CEO meets with Agrium&#146;s senior executives and the
    Senior Human Resources Officer to discuss the specific
    objectives that have been set. The senior executives, in
    consultation with the CEO, set individual performance
    objectives, which are linked to the Corporation&#146;s strategic
    plan, annual business plan and corporate goals. The CEO advises
    the HR&#038;C Committee regarding senior executives&#146;
    objectives and discusses the alignment of the objectives with
    overall strategy.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Reviewing
    Performance and Setting Compensation</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    One of the HR&#038;C Committee&#146;s most important
    responsibilities is making recommendations to the Board
    regarding the CEO&#146;s compensation. In making these
    recommendations, the HR&#038;C Committee evaluates the
    CEO&#146;s performance, including discussion of the
    Corporation&#146;s performance relative to corporate objectives
    and strategic and annual business plans and the CEO&#146;s
    individual performance relative to individual goals. The
    HR&#038;C
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    40
</DIV><!-- END PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN PAGE WIDTH -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Committee reviews the various elements of the CEO&#146;s
    compensation in the context of the total compensation package
    (including salary, annual cash incentive awards, long-term
    equity incentive awards (including prior awards under equity
    compensation plans) and accrued pension benefits) and recommends
    a compensation package. The HR&#038;C Committee&#146;s
    recommendations regarding the CEO&#146;s compensation are
    presented to the independent members of the Board, who together
    determine the CEO&#146;s compensation and provide feedback and
    recommendations in connection with his performance evaluation.
    These recommendations are then reviewed with the CEO by the
    Board Chair and the Chair of the HR&#038;C Committee.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The HR&#038;C Committee consults with the CEO in regard to his
    evaluation of the performance of the executives who report to
    him. The CEO makes recommendations to the HR&#038;C Committee
    regarding executive merit increases, incentive compensation and
    total compensation for executives being hired or promoted. As
    part of the compensation process, the HR&#038;C Committee
    assesses the compensation awarded to the senior executive team
    to ensure that there is appropriate internal equity between
    members of the executive team, such that employees with similar
    responsibilities, experience and historical performance are
    rewarded comparably. The HR&#038;C Committee annually reviews
    total compensation tables prepared by management and the
    consultant for each NEO. A report is also prepared periodically
    to (i) describe trends in termination and change of control
    provisions, (ii) review current provisions applicable to
    Agrium&#146;s senior executives under executive employment
    agreements and (iii) review potential aggregate and incremental
    payment upon employment termination or change of control. The
    overall purpose of these tables and report is to aggregate on a
    uniform basis all of the elements of actual and potential
    executive compensation upon termination and assist the HR&#038;C
    Committee to review the elements of NEO compensation in the
    context of the total compensation package. The HR&#038;C
    Committee&#146;s recommendations regarding the NEOs&#146;
    compensation are presented to the Board, which determines the
    NEOs&#146; compensation and provides feedback and
    recommendations in connection with their performance.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Perks,
    Benefits and Pension Arrangements</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The perks, benefits and pension arrangements offered by the
    Corporation were designed to be competitive with those of
    comparable peer companies and are periodically reviewed by the
    HR&#038;C Committee to ensure that they remain competitive. In
    addition, specific changes to perks, benefits and pension
    arrangements may be submitted to the HR&#038;C Committee for its
    consideration by the compensation consultant or management in
    circumstances where such persons become aware of changes to
    standard industry practices.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Succession
    Planning</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Corporation has a succession management process, which
    manages, tracks and evaluates leadership development and
    succession. The succession process is structured to ensure that
    appropriate candidates are identified and receive appropriate
    development opportunities and exposure to corporate values. A
    report on succession planning processes, organizational
    demographics, and the identification and development of officer
    succession candidates is provided annually to the HR&#038;C
    Committee for its review, input and approval.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Granting
    of Equity Awards</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Typically, the Board grants equity awards of stock options, SARs
    and PSUs on an annual basis at its February meeting, based on
    the recommendations of the HR&#038;C Committee. By making these
    awards at the time it is reviewing performance, the Board and
    the HR&#038;C Committee are able to balance the elements of core
    compensation and align compensation with the Corporation&#146;s
    business strategy. In determining the type and amount of any
    equity grant, the HR&#038;C Committee considers previous grants
    made, including awards which remain unvested
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">and/or</FONT>
    unexercised. In addition, the Corporation has a
    &#147;<B>President&#146;s Award Program</B>&#148; pursuant to
    which, under a delegation of authority by the Board to the
    President&#160;&#038; Chief Executive Officer, the CEO may grant
    awards of stock options and SARs to eligible employees in
    connection with exceptionally meritorious performance,
    promotions and new hires. The President&#146;s Award Program is
    limited as to the aggregate number of stock options and SARs
    that may be awarded thereunder. Since the inception of the
    Program in 1998, there has been an aggregate of 300,000 stock
    options and SARs authorized. An aggregate of 293,300 stock
    options have been granted under the Program, of which 175,275
    have been exercised, and 26,625 have been cancelled (and
    returned to the pool available for future grants), leaving an
    aggregate balance of 33,325 stock options and SARs available to
    be granted. The Program was
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    41
</DIV><!-- END PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN PAGE WIDTH -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    amended in 2006 to authorize an additional aggregate number
    outstanding at any time of up to 20,000 PSUs which may be made
    available and awarded to eligible employees under the Program.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In February 2009, the Corporation adopted an explicit policy
    (the &#147;<B>Option Granting Policy</B>&#148;) to document the
    Corporation&#146;s practices and promote the consistent and
    efficient administration of stock options and SARs, including
    (i)&#160;the procedure for annual grants, (ii)&#160;the
    procedure for one-off grants under the President&#146;s Award
    Program, (iii)&#160;meticulous record keeping, and (iv)&#160;the
    postponement of grants if non-public material information exists
    at the time of any proposed grant.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>
<A name='146'>
<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Basis for
    Compensation Decisions</FONT></B>
</DIV>
</A>
<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Peer
    Groups</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Target compensation levels for Agrium executives are set at the
    median of comparator peer groups. The peer group for
    Agrium&#146;s CEO, CFO and Business Unit Presidents consists of
    U.S.&#160;based chemical and fertilizer companies (the
    &#147;<B>U.S.&#160;Peer Group</B>&#148;) because the competitive
    talent pool for individuals in these positions is largely
    U.S.&#160;based. For other corporate leadership positions,
    including the General Counsel and Corporate Secretary, all
    Senior Vice Presidents, and other executive level positions, the
    peer group consists of a
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">50%/50%</FONT>
    blend of U.S.&#160;chemical peer companies and a select sample
    of comparably sized Canadian companies from a range of
    industrial sectors (the &#147;<B>Mixed Peer Group</B>&#148;).
    The following table provides an overview of the 2008
    U.S.&#160;Peer Group and Mixed Peer Group as compared to the
    Corporation:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV style="font-size: 1pt; margin-left: 0%; width: 13%;  align: left; border-bottom: 1pt solid #000000"></DIV><!-- callerid=999 iwidth=455 length=60 -->



<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 8pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <B>Note:</B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="98%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    <FONT style="font-size: 8pt">(1)
    </FONT></TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    <FONT style="font-size: 8pt">Agrium reports its financial
    results in U.S. dollars. Information concerning peer group
    companies reporting in Canadian dollars has been converted at a
    rate of U.S$1.00 = Cdn.$1.0748, the average annual exchange rate
    for 2007, and is based on Peer Group financial information for
    the 2007 fiscal year.
    </FONT></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 15pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE border="0" width="100%" align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 9pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
<!-- Table Width Row BEGIN -->
<TR style="font-size: 1pt" valign="bottom">
    <TD width="29%">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=01 type=maindata -->
    <TD width="6%">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=02 type=gutter -->
    <TD width="32%">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=02 type=maindata -->
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=03 type=gutter -->
    <TD width="32%">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=03 type=maindata -->
</TR>
<!-- Table Width Row END -->
<TR style="font-size: 8pt" valign="bottom" align="center">
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="bottom">
    <B>Companies in U.S. Peer Group</B>
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    42
</DIV><!-- END PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN PAGE WIDTH -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The HR&#038;C Committee, in consultation with its compensation
    consultant, reviews the U.S.&#160;Peer Group and Mixed Peer
    Group annually to ensure that they continue to be appropriate.
    The peer groups were last reviewed on December&#160;11, 2008, at
    which time the HR&#038;C Committee approved minor amendments to
    both peer groups. The amended peer groups will be used to
    evaluate executive compensation at the completion of fiscal
    2009. The criteria used for determining the companies included
    in the peer groups include that each company is
    (i)&#160;autonomous and publicly-traded, (ii)&#160;has
    comparable revenues to that of Agrium, (iii)&#160;is a capital
    intensive business (e.g. chemicals, energy services, forest
    products, industrial manufacturing, mining and oil&#160;&#038;
    gas), (iv)&#160;is similarly sized considering assets, market
    capitalization and number of employees, and (v)&#160;has robust
    compensation data available.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In addition to the U.S.&#160;Peer Group and Mixed Peer Group,
    Agrium uses a designated group of competitors (the &#147;<B>PSU
    Peer Group</B>&#148;) against which it measures its Total
    Shareholder Return for the purpose of PSU performance vesting.
    The PSU Peer Group has been chosen by the HR&#038;C Committee as
    an appropriate comparator group for measuring total shareholder
    return, as it is representative of investment opportunities for
    equity investors seeking exposure to our industrial sector. Some
    of the members of the PSU Peer Group are included in either one
    or both of the U.S.&#160;Peer Group and Mixed Peer Group;
    however, the U.S.&#160;Peer Group and Mixed Peer Group are
    broader than the PSU Peer Group as they include a range of
    companies against which Agrium competes for executive talent but
    which may not be appropriate for comparing shareholder returns.
    The members of the PSU Peer Group are:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE border="0" width="100%" align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The HR&#038;C Committee, in consultation with its compensation
    consultant, reviews and updates the PSU Peer Group at least
    bi-annually to ensure that it continues to be appropriate. The
    PSU Peer Group was last updated on December&#160;11, 2008.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Target
    Level&#160;Compensation</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The table below sets out (i)&#160;the target level of
    compensation for NEOs assuming desired performance and
    achievement of goals, and (ii)&#160;the manner in which actual
    compensation can vary from the targeted level of compensation.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 15pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE border="0" width="100%" align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 8pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>
</TD>

    Median
    (50<SUP style="font-size: 85%; vertical-align: top">th</SUP><B>&#160;percentile)

    of U.S. Peer Group or Mixed Peer Group (as applicable).<BR>
    <BR>
    Base pay targets matched to comparable roles among peer
    companies.</B>
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD align="left" valign="top">
    Actual base pay will be higher or lower than the median
    depending on the executive&#146;s experience, ongoing
    contribution to the business and level of sustained
    performance.  See &#147;Determining Actual Compensation&#148;
    (below) for specifics on base salary determinations.
</TD>
</TR>

    At target level.
</TD>

<TR valign="bottom">
<TD colspan="5" valign="top">
<DIV style="text-indent: -8pt; margin-left: 8pt">
    <B>Performance Based/At-Risk Compensation</B>
</DIV>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom" style="font-size: 1pt">
<TD colspan="5" style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top">
<DIV style="text-indent: -8pt; margin-left: 8pt">
    <B><I>Annual Incentives</I></B>
</DIV>
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom" style="font-size: 1pt">
<TD colspan="5" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom" style="font-size: 1pt">
<TD colspan="5" style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
<TD align="left" valign="top">
    Profit Sharing Plan and Performance Recognition Plan
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD align="left" valign="top">
    Total annual incentive payout (including payments under both the
    Profit Sharing Plan and Performance Recognition Plan) are
    targeted to the median of U.S. Peer Group or Mixed Peer Group
    (as applicable).
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD align="left" valign="top">
<DIV style="text-indent: -0pt; margin-left: 0pt;">
<I><U>Profit Sharing Plan:<BR><BR></U></I> Performance at the target level will result in &#147;<B>Target</B>&#148; level award.  In 2008, the Target award was 5% of base salary.<BR><BR>Performance significantly above expectation can result in a &#147;<B>Maximum</B>&#148; award.  In 2008, Maximum was 10% of base salary.
</DIV>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD align="left" valign="top">
    Performance below a defined threshold can result in zero Profit
    Sharing Plan incentive payable.
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD align="left" valign="top">
    <I><U>Performance Recognition Plan:</U></I>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD align="left" valign="top">
    Performance at the target level will result in Target level
    award. In 2008, Target award was:
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD align="left" valign="top">
    &#149;&#160;&#160;95% of base salary for CEO, and
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD align="left" valign="top">
    &#149;&#160;&#160;50% to 60% of base salary for other NEOs.
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD align="left" valign="top">
    Performance significantly above expectation can result in a
    Maximum award.  In 2008, Maximum award was:
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD align="left" valign="top">
    &#149;&#160;&#160;190% of base salary for CEO, and
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD align="left" valign="top">
    &#149;&#160;&#160;100% to 120% of base salary for other NEOs.
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD align="left" valign="top">
    Performance below a defined threshold can result in zero
    Performance Recognition Plan incentive payable.
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD align="left" valign="top">
    See &#147;Determining Actual Compensation&#148; (below) for
    specifics on annual incentive compensation determinations.
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom" style="line-height: 6pt">
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top">
<DIV style="text-indent: -8pt; margin-left: 8pt">
    <B><I>Long-Term Incentives</I></B>
</DIV>
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom" style="font-size: 1pt">
<TD colspan="5" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom" style="font-size: 1pt">
<TD colspan="5" style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
<TD align="left" valign="top">
<DIV style="text-indent: -8pt; margin-left: 8pt">
    Stock Options, SARs&#160;&#038; PSUs
</DIV>
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD align="left" valign="top">
    The targeted expected value of grants is in the
    50<SUP style="font-size: 85%; vertical-align: top">th</SUP>&#160;percentile

    (median) of the value of target long-term incentives among  the
    U.S. Peer Group or Mixed Peer Group (as applicable) by level.
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD align="left" valign="top">
    Individual grants can be higher or lower and will reflect the
    level of sustained contribution of each executive.
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD align="left" valign="top">
    In addition, the number of PSUs to vest is performance based and
    additional PSUs may be awarded based on relative shareholder
    return performance (maximum increase in award is 150% if total
    shareholder return is at
    75<SUP style="font-size: 85%; vertical-align: top">th</SUP>&#160;percentile

    or better).
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD align="left" valign="top">
    See &#147;Determining Actual Compensation&#148; (below) for
    specifics on long-term incentive compensation determinations.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Determining
    Actual Compensation</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In December 2008, the HR&#038;C Committee considered the
    Corporation&#146;s compensation program in light of current
    negative economic conditions, including a thorough review of the
    Corporation&#146;s short-term incentive plans. Based on this
    review and other focused discussions through 2008, the HR&#038;C
    Committee believes that the current compensation program
    continues to be appropriate and that no amendments to the
    Corporation&#146;s compensation program were needed to address
    economic conditions at that time. The HR&#038;C Committee will
    continue to monitor the situation.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    44
</DIV><!-- END PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN PAGE WIDTH -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The underlying principle for executive pay throughout the
    Corporation is &#147;pay-for-performance&#148;. The Corporation
    sets clearly defined standards of performance for all variable
    elements of total compensation, and annually defines the level
    of performance required to meet threshold, target and maximum
    pay opportunities. The disclosure contained herein is focused on
    the compensation of the NEOs, and the performance objectives
    discussed below are those which were applicable in the
    determination of NEO compensation in 2008.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Where possible, performance is measured using objective
    performance goals. However, in some circumstances subjective
    measures are more appropriate. Where subjective goals are used
    to measure performance and award compensation, they are defined
    in as detailed a manner as possible so that the evaluator (being
    the HR&#038;C Committee for the CEO and the CEO for the other
    NEOs) can use their business judgment to make an appropriate
    assessment on the basis of evidence presented as to the
    achievement of the goal. All senior executives are evaluated
    against a number of objective goals, and no senior executive is
    evaluated solely on the basis of subjective performance goals.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <I><U><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Corporate
    Performance Objectives</FONT></U></I>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The following table (i)&#160;summarizes the corporate
    performance objectives (including the key performance indicators
    &#147;<B>KPIs</B>&#148;) that are linked to NEO compensation
    determinations, (ii)&#160;sets out the Corporation&#146;s
    performance in 2008 as against these objectives,
    (iii)&#160;identifies the link between each goal and overall
    corporate strategy, and (iv)&#160;identifies the pay element(s)
    to which each goal/objective is connected.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    KPIs are set on the basis of the Corporation&#146;s internal
    budget, where: (i)&#160;&#147;<B>Target</B>&#148; level goals
    identify the performance necessary to achieve the
    Corporation&#146;s budget and receive compensation at the Target
    award level (being the 50th&#160;percentile of the applicable
    peer group), (ii)&#160;&#147;<B>Maximum</B>&#148; level goals
    identify the performance necessary to achieve maximum
    compensation (being the 75th&#160;percentile of the applicable
    peer group), where Maximum goals are generally set at 130% of
    the Target level, and (iii)&#160;&#147;<B>Threshold</B>&#148;
    levels identify the point at which reduced compensation is
    payable and below which no compensation is payable for that
    metric.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 15pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE border="0" width="100%" align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 7pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    or exceeding expectations with respect to having Return on
    Capital Employed
    (ROCE)<SUP style="font-size: 85%; vertical-align: top">(4)</SUP>&#160;in

    excess of Agrium&#146;s weighted average cost of capital.
</TD>

    </FONT>

&nbsp;

    in 2008.
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>

    Disciplined approach to investment<BR>
    <BR>

    determination)
</TD>

<TR valign="bottom" style="font-size: 1pt">

</TD>

    competitiveness by meeting or exceeding budget, including
    targets for Earnings Per Share (EPS) and Operating Cash Flow

    Corporation&#146;s accounts receivable securitization program.

<TD nowrap align="left" valign="bottom">
    <B>2008 Performance
    Goals<SUP style="font-size: 85%; vertical-align: top">(1)(2)</SUP></B>

</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="center" valign="bottom">
    Exceeded
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="center" valign="bottom">

</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="center" valign="bottom">

</TD>
</TR>
<TR style="line-height: 8pt; font-size: 1pt">
<TD>&nbsp;
</TD>

<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top">

</TD>
<TD>

    position in the industry.

    <FONT style="font-family: Wingdings; font-variant: normal">&#252;
    </FONT>
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD align="left" valign="top">
    We achieved our Maximum level performance by delivering on key
    growth priorities and exceeding expectations in this area of
    focus.<SUP style="font-size: 85%; vertical-align: top">(5)</SUP>

</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD align="center" valign="top">
    Grow to Industry Leadership Position<BR>
    <BR>
    Links to Performance Recognition Plan (15% of corporate score
    determination)
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom" style="font-size: 1pt">
<TD colspan="11" align="left" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom" style="font-size: 1pt">
<TD colspan="11" style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="right" valign="top">
    6.
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD align="left" valign="top">
    Show measurable success in creating and sustaining a high
    performance culture, including leadership development, employee
    succession planning and retention. The focus for 2008 was on
    improving employee retention for those in critical roles and for
    those with less than one year of tenure.
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="center" valign="top">
    <FONT style="font-family: Wingdings; font-variant: normal">&#252;
    </FONT>
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD align="left" valign="top">
    We achieved results between our Target and Maximum level goals,
    by initiating employee retention plans across the Corporation
    for critical roles.  In addition, we met or exceeded our target
    with respect to a reduction in employee turnover.
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD align="center" valign="top">
    Create and Sustain a High Performance Culture <BR>
    <BR>
    Links to Performance Recognition Plan (10% of corporate score
    determination)
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom" style="font-size: 1pt">
<TD colspan="11" align="left" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>

<TR valign="bottom" style="font-size: 1pt">
<TD colspan="11" style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">

</TD>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV style="font-size: 1pt; margin-left: 0%; width: 13%;  align: left; border-bottom: 1pt solid #000000"></DIV><!-- callerid=999 iwidth=455 length=60 -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>



<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 8pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <B>Notes:</B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="98%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    <FONT style="font-size: 8pt">(1)
    </FONT></TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    <FONT style="font-size: 8pt">Information regarding performance
    measures is disclosed in the limited context of annual and
    long-term performance based awards and should not be understood
    to be statements of management&#146;s expectations or estimates
    of results or other guidance. Agrium specifically cautions
    investors not to apply these statements in other contexts.
    </FONT></TD>
</TR>


<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    <FONT style="font-size: 8pt">(2)
    </FONT></TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    <FONT style="font-size: 8pt">The Corporation has identified the
    key metrics which are used to determine Profit Sharing Plan and
    Performance Recognition Plan payments. However, as discussed
    above, Maximum, Target and Threshold levels are derived from the
    Corporation&#146;s confidential internal budget, disclosure of
    which would cause competitive harm to the Corporation. As a
    result, the Corporation is not disclosing the specific objective
    targets, but is providing a discussion of the measures used and
    its actual performance in 2008. In 2008, approximately 25% of
    total NEOs&#146; compensation was awarded under the Profit
    Sharing Plan and Performance Recognition Plan. Target level
    performance objectives are intended to be reflective of
    challenging performance in which significant effort is required
    to successfully achieve them (i.e. a 50% chance of exceeding or
    not achieving target). Performance beyond target/plan levels is
    reflective of outstanding performance relative to expectations
    where a sustained level of high performance is required.
    </FONT></TD>
</TR>


<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    <FONT style="font-size: 8pt">(3)
    </FONT></TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    <FONT style="font-size: 8pt">EBITDA is the Corporation&#146;s
    earnings before interest, income taxes, depreciation,
    amortization and asset impairment and is a non-GAAP measure. The
    Corporation uses EBITDA, among other measures, to assess the
    operating performance of its ongoing businesses without the
    effects of amortization expense, net benefit plans cost, and
    restructuring and other items.
    </FONT></TD>
</TR>


<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    <FONT style="font-size: 8pt">(4)
    </FONT></TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    <FONT style="font-size: 8pt">ROCE (Return on Capital Employed)
    is a measure of the return generated by the long-term assets and
    net non-cash working capital of Agrium. ROCE is calculated as
    after-tax EBIT divided by the average long-term assets and net
    non-cash working capital over the year. The resulting ratio
    represents the efficiency with which working capital and
    long-term assets are being utilized to generate EBIT.
    </FONT></TD>
</TR>


<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    <FONT style="font-size: 8pt">(5)
    </FONT></TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    <FONT style="font-size: 8pt">Growth initiatives achieved in 2008
    include: (i)&#160;completing the acquisition of UAP, achieving
    all major integration timelines and thresholds for 2008, and
    surpassing our $20&#160;million target for synergies in 2008;
    (ii)&#160;facilitating an alternative agreement with the
    Egyptian Government to achieve a 26% equity position in the MISR
    Oil and Fertilizers Processing Company S.A.E.
    (&#147;<B>MOPCO</B>&#148;) nitrogen facility (concluded in Q1 of
    2009); (iii)&#160;evaluating expansion of Vanscoy potash
    operations and deciding on expansion plan; (iv)&#160;acquiring a
    70% equity position in CMF, expanding our international
    production and distribution capability beyond North American and
    Argentina; and (v)&#160;continuing to evaluate the potential
    development of a Greenfield potash mine in Saskatchewan or
    Manitoba through an extensive seismic and drilling program.
    </FONT></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <I><U><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">NEO
    Performance Objectives</FONT></U></I>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    NEO performance objectives represent key areas of strategic
    focus for the NEO over the year and are critical to the
    achievement of the Corporation&#146;s business strategy.
    NEO&#146;s individual performance (assessed on the basis of goal
    achievement and responsibilities) is linked to the amount of any
    base salary increase, is a factor in the determination of amount
    of any Performance Recognition Plan payment, and impacts the
    total amount of long-term incentive compensation awarded
    (including grants of options, SARs and PSUs).
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The following table (i)&#160;provides a biography of each NEO
    setting out their key areas of corporate responsibility,
    (ii)&#160;provides a summary of any additional 2008 achievements
    of each NEO, and (iii)&#160;sets out each NEO&#146;s performance
    objectives and performance against such objectives in 2008,
    including (if applicable) descriptions of Business Unit
    performance goals for which an NEO is responsible:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 9pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    46
</DIV><!-- END PAGE WIDTH -->

<TABLE border="0" width="100%" align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 8pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
<!-- Table Width Row BEGIN -->

    <TD width="17%">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=01 type=maindata -->
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=02 type=gutter -->
    <TD width="80%">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=02 type=maindata -->
</TR>
<!-- Table Width Row END -->
<TR valign="bottom">
<TD colspan="3" valign="top">
<DIV style="text-indent: -8pt; margin-left: 8pt">
    <B>Michael M. Wilson</B>
</DIV>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top">
    <IMG src="o53616o5361615.jpg" alt="(WILSON PHOTO)">
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD align="left" valign="top">
    <B>Biography</B>.&#160;&#160;Michael M. Wilson, President &#038;
    Chief Executive Officer, joined Agrium as Executive Vice
    President and Chief Operating Officer in August of 2000.  Mr.
    Wilson is a graduate of the University of Waterloo, Ontario
    where he earned his degree in Chemical Engineering.  He brings
    over 30&#160;years of international and executive management
    experience in the chemical industry.  Prior to joining Agrium,
    Mr. Wilson was President of Methanex Corporation, a leading
    global producer of methanol headquartered in Vancouver, B.C.  In
    addition, he held various senior positions in North America and
    Asia during his 18&#160;years with Dow Chemical.<BR>
    <BR>
    In addition to the achievement of the individual objectives set
    out below, under Mr. Wilson&#146;s leadership, Agrium was
    recognized as the 2007 Canadian Dealmaker of the Year for the
    Materials Industry in connection with the UAP transaction.  In
    addition, Mr. Wilson was named Calgary businessman of the year
    in 2008.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TD>

<TD nowrap align="center" valign="bottom">

    <B>2008 Result</B>
</DIV>

<TR valign="bottom">
<TD align="left" valign="top">
    The successful completion of the UAP acquisition and subsequent
    integration of its operations.
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="center" valign="top">
    <FONT style="font-family: Wingdings; font-variant: normal">&#252;
    </FONT>
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD align="left" valign="top">
    The Corporation successfully completed the UAP acquisition in
    May 2008 and surpassed our $20-million target for synergies in
    2008 despite the later than expected closing of the transaction.
</TD>
</TR>
<TR style="font-size: 1pt">
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top" style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">

<TD nowrap align="center" valign="top" style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">

<TD style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">
&nbsp;

<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top" style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
<TD align="left" valign="top">
    The attainment of the Corporation&#146;s financial targets by
    utilizing our strong cash flow to reduce debt incurred in the
    acquisition of UAP.
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="center" valign="top">
    <FONT style="font-family: Wingdings; font-variant: normal">&#252;
    </FONT>
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD align="left" valign="top">
    The Corporation achieved desired financial leverage ratios much
    sooner than originally forecast as a result of prudent balance
    sheet management and strong earnings across all of our business
    units.
</TD>
</TR>
<TR style="font-size: 1pt">
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top" style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">

</TD>
<TD nowrap align="center" valign="top" style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">
&nbsp;

<TD style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top" style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
<TD align="left" valign="top">
    Achieve targeted progression with the development of the
    Corporation&#146;s Egyptian nitrogen facility towards its full
    operation by late 2010.
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="center" valign="top">
    <FONT style="font-family: Wingdings; font-variant: normal">&#252;
    </FONT>
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD align="left" valign="top">
    A major challenge in 2008 was local opposition to the
    Corporation&#146;s original nitrogen project in Egypt. The
    facility was partially built when the government halted
    construction early in 2008. While we were clearly disappointed
    with these events, our project team was successful in
    facilitating an alternative agreement with the Egyptian
    Government that maintained a majority of the project&#146;s
    value under difficult circumstances.  The MOPCO nitrogen
    facility is a world-scale facility located in a geographic
    region with highly-competitively priced gas and prime shipping
    access to key markets.  The agreement provides Agrium with a 26%
    equity position in the facility which will generate immediate
    earnings.
</TD>
</TR>
<TR style="font-size: 1pt">
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top" style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="center" valign="top" style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top" style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
<TD align="left" valign="top">
    Reach a final decision regarding the next-phase expansion to our
    Vanscoy potash operations by the fourth quarter of 2008.
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="center" valign="top">
    <FONT style="font-family: Wingdings; font-variant: normal">&#252;
    </FONT>
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD align="left" valign="top">
    The Corporation evaluated expansion options at the Vanscoy
    facility and decided to proceed with the next phase of
    development for the project that is expected to increase the
    mine&#146;s sustainable annual production capacity to 2.8
    million tonnes. The first phase of the project would be expected
    to be completed by the second half of 2012.
</TD>
</TR>
<TR style="font-size: 1pt">
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top" style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>

&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top" style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
<TD align="left" valign="top">
    Evaluate projects to improve energy utilization and provide
    alternative feedstock as backup for the Profertil facility.
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="center" valign="top">
    <FONT style="font-family: Wingdings; font-variant: normal">&#252;
    </FONT>
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD align="left" valign="top">
    The Corporation successfully utilized imported liquid natural
    gas as backup feedstock to maintain operating rates at our
    Profertil facility during the months of tightest natural gas
    supply in Argentina.
</TD>
</TR>
<TR style="font-size: 1pt">
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top" style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="center" valign="top" style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top" style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
<TD align="left" valign="top">
    Reach a final decision regarding capacity expansion for our
    Advanced Technologies controlled-release ESN product line.
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="center" valign="top">
    <FONT style="font-family: Wingdings; font-variant: normal">&#252;
    </FONT>
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD align="left" valign="top">
    The Corporation decided to proceed with constructing a new
    ESN<SUP style="font-size: 85%; vertical-align: text-top">&#174;</SUP>

    in-market coating facility, with an expected capacity of 110,000
    tonnes of
    ESN<SUP style="font-size: 85%; vertical-align: text-top">&#174;</SUP>,

    which is expected to be completed in 2010.  We also expect to
    expand our
    ESN<SUP style="font-size: 85%; vertical-align: text-top">&#174;</SUP>

    capacity by approximately 20,000 tonnes annually at our
    Sylacauga, Alabama facility starting in 2009.  These two
    expansions would bring our total annual
    ESN<SUP style="font-size: 85%; vertical-align: text-top">&#174;</SUP>

    capacity to 325,000 tonnes.
</TD>
</TR>
<TR style="font-size: 1pt">
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top" style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="center" valign="top" style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">
&nbsp;

<TR valign="bottom">
<TD align="left" valign="top">

    and distribution capability beyond North America and Argentina.
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="center" valign="top">
    <FONT style="font-family: Wingdings; font-variant: normal">&#252;
    </FONT>
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD align="left" valign="top">
    The Corporation acquired a 70% equity position in CMF, a Western
    European fertilizer distribution company with annual crop
    nutrient sales volumes of more than 2 million tonnes. This
    acquisition expands our distribution into France, Germany,
    Belgium, the U.K., Italy, Bulgaria, Spain, the Netherlands,
    Ireland, Greece, Denmark and South America.
</TD>
</TR>
<TR style="font-size: 1pt">
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top" style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">

</TD>
<TD nowrap align="center" valign="top" style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">
&nbsp;

<TD style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top" style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
<TD align="left" valign="top">
    Continue to evaluate and act on opportunities for value-added
    growth across the value chain.
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="center" valign="top">
    <FONT style="font-family: Wingdings; font-variant: normal">&#252;
    </FONT>
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD align="left" valign="top">
    The Corporation continued to evaluate the potential development
    of a greenfield potash mine in Western Canada through an
    extensive seismic and drilling program carried out in 2008.
    Production would not be expected prior to 2015.
</TD>
</TR>
<TR style="font-size: 1pt">
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top" style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="center" valign="top" style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top" style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
<TD align="left" valign="top">
    Further advance development of the Corporation&#146;s executive
    succession candidates.
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="center" valign="top">
    <FONT style="font-family: Wingdings; font-variant: normal">&#252;
    </FONT>
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD align="left" valign="top">
    An updated executive succession plan was formulated and was
    presented to and approved by the Board for implementation in
    2009.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

    <B>Bruce G. Waterman</B>
</DIV>

<TR valign="bottom">
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top">

<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD align="left" valign="top">
<B>Biography.</B>&#160;&#160;Bruce G. Waterman joined Agrium as
Senior Vice President, Finance &#038; Chief Financial Officer,
in April of 2000.  In this role, Mr. Waterman is responsible for
Treasury, Tax, Investor Relations, Controllers, Information
Technology and Government Relations.  Mr. Waterman is a graduate
of Queen&#146;s University in Ontario where he earned his degree
in Commerce in 1973.  He achieved his Chartered Accountant
designation in 1975.  Mr. Waterman brings more than
30&#160;years of financial and management experience to his role
at Agrium. Prior to joining Agrium, Mr. Waterman served as Vice
President, Finance &#038; Chief Financial Officer of Talisman
Energy in Calgary.<BR>
<BR>
In addition to the achievement of the individual objectives set
out below, Mr. Waterman was the 2008 recipient of the
Canada&#146;s CFO of the
Year<FONT style="font-variant: SMALL-CAPS"><SUP style="font-size: 85%; vertical-align: top">tm</SUP></FONT>

Award, sponsored by Financial Executives International Canada,
PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP, and Caldwell Partners International.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

<TD align="left" valign="top">
    <B>Biography.</B>&#160;&#160;Richard L. Gearheard has served as
    Senior Vice President of Agrium and President of the Retail
    Business Unit since August 1996.  He has also worked in various
    capacities with other Agrium Retail companies such as Western
    Farm Service as Vice President, Northwest Region and Crop
    Production Services as Vice President and Chief Financial
    Officer.  In 1983, he participated in the formation of Crop
    Production Services through a leveraged buyout.  During his
    career, he has been involved with company-changing acquisitions
    including PureGro, Western Farm Service and Royster-Clark.

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV style="font-size: 1pt; margin-left: 0%; width: 13%;  align: left; border-bottom: 1pt solid #000000"></DIV><!-- callerid=999 iwidth=455 length=60 -->



<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 8pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <B>Note:</B>
</DIV>



<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="98%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    <FONT style="font-size: 8pt">(1)
    </FONT></TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    <FONT style="font-size: 8pt">The term EBIT refers to earnings
    before interest expense and income taxes. The Corporation
    believes that EBIT is useful supplemental information as it
    provides an indication of the results generated by the
    Company&#146;s main business activities prior to taking into
    consideration how those activities are financed or taxed. EBIT
    is a non-GAAP earnings measure that does not have standardized
    measures prescribed by GAAP, and therefore may not be comparable
    to similar measures presented by other publicly traded companies.
    </FONT></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    49
</DIV><!-- END PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->

</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD align="left" valign="top">
    <B>Biography.</B>&#160;&#160;Ron A. Wilkinson is Senior Vice
    President, Agrium and President of the Wholesale Business Unit.
    Mr. Wilkinson joined Agrium in 1996 through the acquisition of
    Viridian Inc.  and held positions with the organization
    including Vice President Operations and Technology, Director,
    Technical Services, General Manager of South American
    Operations, General Manager of Operations and Projects, Asia
    Pacific, and Manager of Transportation.  Mr. Wilkinson has also
    worked for Sherritt Inc., Imperial Oil, Exxon Chemical Pakistan
    Limited and Esso Chemical Canada.  Mr. Wilkinson has over thirty
    years engineering, operations and business management experience
    within the petrochemical industry.  A graduate of the University
    of Alberta with a B.Sc.  in Chemical Engineering, Mr. Wilkinson
    also completed &#147;The Executive Program&#148; at the
    University of Virginia, Darden School of Business in 1993. He is
    a member of The Association of Professional Engineers,
    Geologists and Geophysicists of Alberta (APEGGA).
</TD>

<DIV style="text-indent: -0pt; margin-left: 0pt;">
<B>Biography.</B>&#160;&#160;Leslie O&#146;Donoghue has been employed at Agrium since 1999 and currently holds the position of Senior Vice President, General Counsel &#038; Corporate Secretary.  Ms. O&#146;Donoghue&#146;s responsibilities include legal affairs, corporate governance, internal audit, environmental, health, safety &#038; security, as well as functional support for mergers and acquisitions.  Prior to joining Agrium, Ms. O&#146;Donoghue was a partner at Blake, Cassels &#038; Graydon LLP.  After earning her Economics degree from the University of Calgary in 1984, Ms. O&#146;Donoghue completed her LL.B. at Queen&#146;s University in 1988, and was admitted to the Alberta Bar in 1989.<BR><BR>Ms. O&#146;Donoghue established the Agrium&#146;s Women&#146;s Leadership Group (AWLG) and organizes AWLG forums and networking with related professional groups.</DIV>

</TD>
<TD align="left" valign="top">
    Consolidated employee total recordable injuries, lost time
    incidents, and environmental incident rates all exceeded
    performance goals. Work place safety index for 2008 improved by
    13% and contractor injury rate improved by 40%.
</TD>
</TR>
<TR style="font-size: 1pt">
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top" style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="center" valign="top" style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top" style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
<TD align="left" valign="top">
    Continuous improvement in implementation of environmental,
    health, safety&#160;&#038; security governance best practices.
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="center" valign="top">
    <FONT style="font-family: Wingdings; font-variant: normal">&#252;
    </FONT>
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD align="left" valign="top">
    Establishment of four internal technical EHS&#038;S governance
    committees in risk management, product stewardship, security
    &#038; crisis management, and environmental liability management
    to identify, develop, implement and communicate best practices,
    resulting in enhancements to environmental management systems.
    Establishment of visionary goals and Improvement Plan through
    2010 for EHS&#038;S key performance indicators.
</TD>
</TR>
<TR style="font-size: 1pt">
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="bottom" style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="bottom" style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="bottom" style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    51
</DIV><!-- END PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN PAGE WIDTH -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 4pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <I><U><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Setting
    2008 NEO Compensation</FONT></U></I>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 2pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The following table sets out the basis for compensation
    decisions with respect to each element of NEO compensation in
    2008:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 2pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE border="0" width="100%" align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
<!-- Table Width Row BEGIN -->
<TR style="font-size: 1pt" valign="bottom">
    <TD width="17%">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=01 type=maindata -->
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=02 type=gutterleft -->
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=02 type=gutterright -->
    <TD width="81%">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=02 type=maindata -->
</TR>
<!-- Table Width Row END -->
<TR style="font-size: 1pt" valign="bottom" align="center">
<TD colspan="4" align="center" valign="bottom" style="font-size: 1pt; border-bottom: 1px solid #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
<TD align="left" valign="top">
    <B>Base Salary<BR>
    <BR>
    </B><FONT style="font-size: 8pt">See the &#147;Summary<BR>
    Compensation<BR>
    Table&#148; (below) for<BR>
    the total base salary<BR>
    paid to each NEO<BR>
    during fiscal 2008,<BR>
    2007, and 2006.
    </FONT>
</TD>
<TD style="border-right: 1px solid #000000; padding-right: 2pt">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD align="left" valign="top">
    As discussed above, base salary adjustments may be the result of
    (i) competitive salary adjustments (&#147;<B>Competitive
    Adjustment</B>&#148;) where needed to ensure that salary levels
    remain competitive on the basis of peer group market data (being
    the U.S. Peer Group or Mixed Peer Group, as applicable), (ii)
    merit increases (&#147;<B>Merit Increase</B>&#148;) where needed
    to reward superior performance (NEO goals and performance in
    2008 are set out under &#147;NEO Performance Objectives&#148;
    (above)), and (iii) promotional increases
    (&#147;<B>Responsibility Increase</B>&#148;) in circumstances
    where an officer has been promoted to a position of increased
    responsibility and/or has taken on increased responsibility in
    his or her existing role.
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD style="border-right: 1px solid #000000; padding-right: 2pt">
&nbsp;
</TD>

&nbsp;
</TD>

    <B>2008 Base Salary</B>.  NEO base salaries paid in 2008 are as
    follows:
</TD>

    (1)&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;Base salary is set for the period
    commencing March 1 of each year, following the completion of
    performance reviews. &#147;2007 Base Pay&#148; reflects the
    amount paid to NEOs from March&#160;1, 2007 to February&#160;29,
    2008. &#147;2008 Base Pay&#148; reflects the amount paid to NEOs
    from March&#160;1, 2008 to February&#160;28, 2009.

    <B><FONT style="font-size: 10pt">2009 Base
    Salary</FONT></B><FONT style="font-size: 10pt">.  The HR&#038;C
    Committee decided not to make any adjustments to NEOs&#146; base
    salaries for 2009, as current base salaries were determined to
    be appropriate and competitive.
    </FONT>

    <B>Perks, Benefits, &#038; Pension<BR>

    No changes to the standard NEO perks, benefits or retirement
    plans (as described under the section entitled
    &#147;Compensation Program Design&#148; (above)) were made in
    2008.
